Contents: It would be nice to be able to download the original game on the new systems. Before anyone says something to the effect of "Payday2 has the original levels"- I understand however, the new game lacks the original game mechanics. Like most people who upgraded to the new baked potato systems, we no longer have the PS3 or XBox360 systems. The game is (pretty much) finished as far as patches go. There would be no need to do anything except send it out to our respective digital stores for redistribution. PAYDAY: The Heist was the SH%T. I think the other Veteran players would agree. Sure, the PC got one last patch that removed the bag glitch and added a few enemies is various maps. If they wanted to include the final version of the game, that'd be great. Otherwise, I'd be okay with just getting the game again in any form. PDTH was so much more competitive and a re-release to the newer systems would bring the console veterans back as well as introduce NEW players to this franchise. The Heist, in comparison to 2 is more easier to just hop in a game and go rob something by yourself or with friends. It's not as intimidating to look at for *new players. Thoughts? ====================::==================== You are comparing apples to potatoes, genius. Ofcourse you would have to use a controller.. We're talking about consoles. I own the game on PS3 & PC. I also bought Payday 2 on Ps3 PS4 and PC. Spending an extra 30 bucks won't kill anyone. That's if they even want to charge for the game at this point being as dated as it is. Just to make it free would make them money by introducing new players that are not ready for the menu-based style of gameplay that PD2 has to offer. You are speaking hypothetically as if there is no fan base for PDTH on consoles. Get real. You have NO clue how big the playerbase was because you were not part of it. I was. The game was once available on Playstation Now as a 10 day trial or something. So, it was able to be streamed. Albeit a lower resolution and framerate. It was still there. PDTH for PS4/XB1? Contents: FireDrakeZ posted... Viper187666 posted... FireDrakeZ posted... Not at all. I might get the upcoming PS5 if it has back compatibility. For this gen though, I think the Xbox One X is a much better console alternative. The PS4's lack of back compatibility is a major drawback. BTW, I am just responding to the PS4 fanboys here who do nothing but attack me for choosing the Xbox One X. Otherwise I am okay with whatever console you prefer and don't even bring it up. Maybe you should accuse them of shilling for Sony. Sure I do point why I feel the Xbox One X is the better console for this gen but at least I try to be logical and civil in my response unlike many on the other side. I do like the fact that Microsoft continues to add features beyond what they already have on launch day. I don't even use BC on Xbox because I have like 7 x360s. However, PS4 not having BC pisses me off because I absolutely hate the PS3. It was underpowered, and I hate top loaders (had a fat one, but BD drive wore out). I'd really like all those exclusives ported to PS4. Sony has been very slow to even do that. ONE God of War game? Come the f*** on. Give us the whole HD collection. Yup. That is why I might consider PS5 if they add back compatibility, although to be honest with a gaming PC, I can access those few PS3 and PS4 exclusives already via PSNow anyway. As for the Xbox One X's back compatibility feature, its major advantage has been the ability to enhance those 360 games to take advantage of the One X's specs. Some 360 games like Witcher 2, can now even be played at 4K. Yeah, I'm annoyed they haven't enhanced PD0 yet. It was kind of a big deal as an exclusive launch title (or near launch?) on 360 and all. nan

Try to keep this short as I know this is a major known issue with FO3 running on Win 10. I have Steam GOTY Edition. It ran Vanilla with compatibility tweaks (ran compatible with XP SP3). Also, installed FOSE with compatibility, upped the .exe to 4 GB and set affinity for game at 2 cores. It ran even better seemed more stable. I also Installed Unofficial Patch. Okay now for MODS.; Fellout-Full, Enhanced Blood, Flora Overhaul, Colt M4 Carbines, GNR Enhanced, AKS74U, MMMFO, Sprint Mod, DC Interiors, Real World Drinks, Hi Res Weapons and the NMC Large Texture Pack. I had more loaded but it would crash shortly after execution (if it would even execute) so I scaled down my MOD selection. To my shock and surprise the game executed and loaded. 30 hours I had spent trying and troubleshooting. I was able to start a New Game. Played for several hours with only one crash. I got to Megaton (crashed again as I exited the vault but loaded save and worked swell thereafter for a while). I was so stoked, I had never seen FO3 like this I played it 10 years ago on console and never dreamed how good it could look now that I have a gaming CPU. I have an Alienware 15, getting a little long in the tooth in 2018 but it was smoking FO3. I did my thing at Megaton and played around with some console commands still chugging along. Then... I leave Megaton heading north and every time I get just beyond Sunnyvale, where you can see the large overpass it goes kaput. Only thing I can think is maybe Fellout or the NMC pack is adding in to much detail and I am running the game on ultra high settings. I played around with it a bit still no luck. I really don't want to lose Fellout mod it looks so amazing. IDK, if any of you friends read this and know something I haven't tried (and yes I have rifled through the forums and threads or as much as I could and still no dice) save me from having to play FO3 on ...gulp... PSNow . Oh the graphics are shhait and interface even worse. If you have read this far thanks much obliged. Sincerely, Hopeless Gamer in The OC (RehabJip) ====================::==================== Mods with multiple plugins must be arranged in the same order as the game DLCs, with the main .esp first. You need to re-arrange Mart's Mutant Mod and remove unused plugins. Do not rely on LOOT to sort your mods. It does not now nor has it ever sorted FO3 mods correctly. Edited by M48A5, Today, 12:56 AM. I'm tired and just wanna play? Anything I haven't tried? HELP! Fallout 3 Technical Support

Contents: Whatever happens, the company on the bottom will always play the "good guy" card. Last gen with the 360 owning the market share, microsoft hid streaming like Netflix behind a live paywall, and made gamers pay for DLC that was free on PC (left 4 dead.) Sony responded with free online and started the free games every month program we all have today. Today with sony's domination of the market share, microsoft has adopted the good guy approach with BC and constant updates. Sony now, blocked large file mods, slow updates (how long did we have to wait for external HD support?) And wants to push PSNow rather than BC. So no matter who is winning the race, you can bet the one in 2nd is working harder for your dime. nan

Try to keep this short as I know this is a major known issue with FO3 running on Win 10. I have Steam GOTY Edition. It ran Vanilla with compatibility tweaks (ran compatible with XP SP3). Also, installed FOSE with compatibility, upped the .exe to 4 GB and set affinity for game at 2 cores. It ran even better seemed more stable. I also Installed Unofficial Patch. Okay now for MODS.; Fellout-Full, Enhanced Blood, Flora Overhaul, Colt M4 Carbines, GNR Enhanced, AKS74U, MMMFO, Sprint Mod, DC Interiors, Real World Drinks, Hi Res Weapons and the NMC Large Texture Pack. I had more loaded but it would crash shortly after execution (if it would even execute) so I scaled down my MOD selection. To my shock and surprise the game executed and loaded. 30 hours I had spent trying and troubleshooting. I was able to start a New Game. Played for several hours with only one crash. I got to Megaton (crashed again as I exited the vault but loaded save and worked swell thereafter for a while). I was so stoked, I had never seen FO3 like this I played it 10 years ago on console and never dreamed how good it could look now that I have a gaming CPU. I have an Alienware 15, getting a little long in the tooth in 2018 but it was smoking FO3. I did my thing at Megaton and played around with some console commands still chugging along. Then... I leave Megaton heading north and every time I get just beyond Sunnyvale, where you can see the large overpass it goes kaput. Only thing I can think is maybe Fellout or the NMC pack is adding in to much detail and I am running the game on ultra high settings. I played around with it a bit still no luck. I really don't want to lose Fellout mod it looks so amazing. IDK, if any of you friends read this and know something I haven't tried (and yes I have rifled through the forums and threads or as much as I could and still no dice) save me from having to play FO3 on ...gulp... PSNow . Oh the graphics are shhait and interface even worse. If you have read this far thanks much obliged. Sincerely, Hopeless Gamer in The OC (RehabJip) I'm tired and just wanna play? Anything I haven't tried? HELP! - Fallout 3 Technical Support

This is not an option that has matured enough or even available when it comes to most Xbox games on the PC. Combining my gaming PC with the Xbox One X's ability to play back compatible games over 3 generations of Xbox consoles gives my setup much more game coverage than with other console-PC combinations. nan

Contents: I feel you on Alpha 3. That's the game that really got me into Street Fighter. I had a buddy of mine that I'd play against; I was always Ken, and he'd take Shin Akuma. We still split our matches, despite him spamming air fireballs and being able to pull off that super move that takes half your life if it lands. If you liked The Thousand-Year Door, I can't imagine you not enjoying the first game.Â  Give it a go when you have a chance! Guess I can roll into PlayStation now, too.Â  I bet y'all can guess the number one spot! Castlevania: Symphony of the Night.Â  A timeless classic.Â  The best PlayStation game ever made in my eyes.Â  I routinely revisit it, and have an absolute blast every single time.Â  Sure, the difficulty is pretty uneven (mostly easy), but there are just so many little touches that you can tell it was a labor of love from start to finish. Valkyrie Profile might be crazy obtuse for that hidden ending, but dang if it's not one of the best RPGs on the system.Â  I just love the general feel of the game, and the lore involved.Â  You feel like all your Einherjar are real people with real stories, and that's awesome.Â  Uh, my current profile pic is also a drawing I did of Arngrim from some time ago, so...Â  yeah, I'd say the game resonated with me. Arc the Lad II hit me as a combination of Chrono Trigger and Shining Force.Â  It might be my favorite SRPG of all time.Â  Absolutely recommended, although you might want to start with the first game; it's rather short, but sets the stage well for the second game.Â  The scope of AtLII dwarfs that of the first game. To mix things up, I'll take a rather jubilant game:Â  Ape Escape.Â  The N64 had the 3D platformer scene pretty much locked down, but darn if Ape Escape didn't make a run for the crown.Â  I loved figuring out how to capture those monkeys with all the cool gadgets you get.Â  This game also required the use of the Dual Shock, and made excellent use of it.Â  Highly, highly recommended. This is where things get tough.Â  I've got a bunch of games vying for the fifth spot, but much like my choice on NES with Tecmo Super Bowl, I'm going to go with sheer hours invested.Â  That means Street Fighter Alpha 3 makes it in.Â  This was one of the best arcade conversions on the PSX, a system that often paled in comparison to the Saturn for these games.Â  Capcom really went all out on making this particular version run better on the system.Â  Plus, that World Tour mode was crazy fun. There are tons of other games I could have listed, but the four that got pushed out were: Metal Gear Solid, Alundra, Suikoden II, and Vagrant Story. Symphony of the Night Valkyrie Profile Arc the Lad II Ape Escape Street Fighter Alpha 3 Your Top 5's per system!
Post Title: Your Top 5's per system!

Contents: I realize I'm alone when I say this..i loved 6. LOVED IT. Fast-paced, non-stop action, soooo much content, cool bosses, gone with the stupid and repetitive puzzles, fun monster invasion mode. Perfect control mechanism, finally able to run quick and do sliding attacks and flying kicks, feels fluid. Great soundtrack, loved the menu style at the beginning, the crossover battles. The first few levels of Leo's campaign are insanely fun, i especially enjoyed the diner scene where you first see the fat hulk zombie and it's wall-to-wall zombies climbing through windows. Honestly I'd read bad reviews about the game so didn't expect much, but I was absolutely baffled by how no-one could love it after I was 30 mins in. Ah man, how can anyone diss RE6?? It's like the drive-thru of video games-- got 20 mins during lunch for a quick dose of adrenaline? Just drop into anyone's game! I think it's because it was on PSNow and basically free that I liked it so much. Had I paid $70 then I probably would've been disappointed, yeah. I also think people that hate 6 are the ones that loved the old RE style pre 4-- the slow, creepy foreboding vibe, and I can understand that, you can't rightfully call them by the same title. nan

The_Hedon posted... Mario786 posted... @The_Hedon posted... Mario786 posted... BeefEaster posted... it's the MS equivalent of sony's deep down Deep Down is Capcom. Deep Down is being developed by SIE Japan Studio and Capcom. He was correct. Nope SIE has nothing to do with it, it's a Capcom IP, developed by Capcom and published by Capcom. Just look at the trailer, no mention of Sony anywhere. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ivwgE_t8a5s As opposed to say Bloodborne, which opens with the Sony and Japan Studio logos. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G203e1HhixY You know what IS a Sony game that's taking a while to come out is Death Stranding, but I guess it's not as excruciating a wait as Crackdown since Death Stranding was announced a full two years later. https://www.keengamer.com/Game/deep-down/detail Deep Down is an upcoming role-playing video game by Capcom and SIE Japan Studio for the PlayStation 4. Deep Down is an upcoming single/multiplayer coop dungeon crawler under development by Capcom for the PlayStation 4. Wikipedia Release: WW: TBA Engine: Panta Rhei Publisher: Capcom Genre: Action role-playing game Developers: Capcom, SIE Japan Studio Platform: PlayStation 4 https://www.reddit.com/r/deepdown/ Publisher: Capcom Developers: SCE Japan Studio and Capcom Online Games Engine: Phata Rei Genre: Free-to-play Action RPG Platform: PS4 https://ipfs.io/ipfs/QmXoypizjW3WknFiJnKLwHCnL72vedxjQkDDP1mXWo6uco/wiki/Deep_Down_(video_game).html Deep Down is the working title[1] for an upcoming action role-playing developed by Capcom and SIE Japan Studio for the PlayStation 4.[2] Deep Down is a single-player game with the option to have up to four players in co-op multiplayer, with random players dropping into the player's world to help them defeat monsters and find artifacts.[3] ------------------------- I am going to be patient for Death Stranding. With the game coming to PS4 first, followed by PC, it will be worth waiting for the PC version for the better performance and graphics. Those are not official sources and just mistakes on the part of whoever made typed up the info. If Deep Down was developed by Studio Japan then Sony would own the IP, Sony does not have their studios working on IPs not owned by Sony. Also you can give up hopes of Death Stranding PC as It's a Sony owned game now and they don't tend to release their games on PC. You might get it through PSNOW 3-5 years after it releases, though PSNOW isn't the ideal way to play games, especially for someone who cares about graphics and performance. nan

Contents: Originally posted by R||||DGE RACER: Originally posted by Lazy Zombi: most of the PS3 and PS4 exclusives are now on PC, or coming to PC through Sony's PlayStation Now, extremely overpriced, service. Aside from that very very very small handful of rather boring titles, all other games on PS3 are on PC, in fact, nearly every non exclusive is right here on Steam. PlayStation Now streams the games from a PS3/PS4 system. The game does not run on a PC. The games are not on a PC. They are still exclusive to PS3/PS4, and you are paying for an inferior experience (games natively run better on the actual systems) They're available to be played on a PC. Simple as that. Regardless, most of the PlayStation exclusives are garbage anyway, so it doesn't really matter. However, if I had wanted to play the games, I'd much rather pay $15 a month for a few months until I played them all, than to overpay $400 on a piece ofâ™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥console that can't even manage 60 FPS 1080p in most modern games. Not to mention all the other fees associated with buying and owning a console. Pc or Console

Contents:
Xbox E3 Press Conference Dated As Microsoft Makes Changes For â€œBiggest Showing Everâ€
 Microsoft has officially confirmed its plans for E3 2018. Rather than have its usual presence inside the Los Angeles Convention Center, where E3 takes place, Microsoft is moving the bulk of its efforts across the street to the nearby Microsoft Theater in LA Live. The company says this will make for the companyâ€™s â€œbiggest E3 showing ever.â€
 First up at the Microsoft Theater will be Microsoftâ€™s E3 press conference, which is scheduled to take place on Sunday, June 10, at 1 PM PT. Following that, it will host Xbox FanFest events, hands-on demos for E3 attendees, and more. â€œNot only does the Microsoft Theater allow us to centralize our Xbox presence at E3, but its size enables us to include even more fans and partners in the Xbox E3 2018 Briefing than ever before,â€ said corporate VP Mike Nichols in anÂ Xbox WireÂ post.  The announcement makes it clear that the move was made in collaboration with the ESA, no doubt to avoid spurring discussions about E3â€™s demise. Microsoft also points out that it wonâ€™t be absent entirely from the official E3 show floor, as it will have a booth for its streaming service, Mixer.  â€œThese changesâ€“expanding our presence, multiple venues, taking over the Microsoft Theaterâ€“give us the opportunity to bring together a variety of Xbox experiences into one primary location and, most importantly, let fans in on what weâ€™re up to in 2018 and beyond in a fresh new way,â€ Nichols said.  At this point, we have little idea of what to expect from Microsoftâ€™s E3 showing. Whereas last year we knew that Xbox One X (then Project Scorpio) would be a major highlight, this yearâ€™s show remains more of a mystery. Xbox boss Phil Spencer said in January that there would be someÂ â€œpositive changesâ€ at E3 for Microsoft, which may have been a reference to the just-announced move. One possibility is the announcement ofHalo 6, which has been discussed but not formally revealed. Microsoft is also said to be working on aÂ PlayStation Now-like game-streaming service. 

 via Blogger http://ift.tt/2GrUjWj nan

Contents: Quote: : â†‘ Mar 20th, 2018 1:50 am That may explain it. as in the big cities and malls, this "Open but New" scenario is *extremely* common due to limited floor/shelf space - they treat new games the same as used and store them in paper sleeves to save space. Which is exactly why everyone should just buy elsewhere. If you were to buy a game, open the cello wrap, and turn around to trade it in theyâ€™d consider it used so why canâ€™t the customers. ====================::==================== once again i apologize for the poor sentence structure. when i'm typing i'm not paying attention to periods and paragraphs. so i agree i can make them run on... just bare (sp?) with me. the store in question is located in the pen centre in st. kitts. and i'm not going to mention the employee (aka - the store manager) by name since i think head office has already had a talk with them and now i may have an issue if it comes to having to go and pick up the codes. i find it quite funny that with more recent releases such as the call of duty WWII they can print DLC codes at the bottom of the receipt, yet they can't seem to do the same with steep or ghost recon. ghost recon especially since it's the newest of the two and it's still getting dlc and updates. yes, i know some dlc is only available at pre-order and day one release. BUT it can be done... and you would think if they can arrange it or dig up some codes that may still be valid why not just do that and have a satisfied customer rather than fan the flames of an irritated customer to the point they would never shop there again. heck, i could be that one customer that comes in a drops hundreds compared to the one that only buys a pair of cheap socks and a $1 cheap bin spinner. i get a chuckle out of these idiots that once promoted to store manager and given the key to the front and back door they think they actual hold some sort of power. lol, you're a game store salesperson.... who at any time could wind up unemployed if head office felt your location wasn't producing the sales they were expecting. if anyone wants to know what goes on at eb/gamestop i suggest you look up a youtube person by the name of "fantavision". he talks about working at gamestop and all sorts of stuff they would pull... including selling back free games they would get at conventions AND selling/claiming codes that were included in new games. one thing he does touch on is this. every new game eb/gamestop sells the developer gets a cut of, so they open the games and some they would claim as used so they would not have to give the developer their cut. it's hard for the developer to prove which is which since they claim they opened the game for "display purposes". gamestop then claims the game as open and used BUT to a customer such as myself, they claim it as new opened product to still get the full retail pricing. this was one reason why microsoft decided to include new releases in their version of PSnow... to cut out the middleman. and isn't it funny how of all the places like walmart, best buy, target, etc. that eb games/gamestop is the one complaining the loudest about potential loss of sales. at least walmart, target and best buy have other stuff in their stores to keep them afloat while eb/gamestop doesn't really. sure they have branched out to become hot topic lite, but places like hot topic have the better deals and clearance racks compared to the latter. so i'm thinking if sony follows suit to compete with microsoft that would leave eb/gamestop really struggling since they would depend on older games at that point... ones that aren't on the PSnow and xbox comparable. and even then, other game shops would sell the older games at a better price. my relative was actually able to get their steep dlc. they bought it through xbox live and actually got it included in another dlc free. so they are happy. and i get the free updates from ghost recon so i'm not upset. eb games employees using codes from new games.. - Page 3
Post Title: eb games employees using codes from new games.. - Page 3

Contents: As another person said, if youâ€™ve got the coin, get PS3 and a copy. To be honest, RDR is the only reason I keep my PS3 anymore and itâ€™s worth every bit of room it takes up just to have that ability to play. So far it seems that Canada is the only area that doesnâ€™t have issues. I have a friend in Vancouver Island who plays it on PSNow and she says she never has issues, but here itâ€™s just so unreliable. Half the time you canâ€™t see what youâ€™re doing because the quality drops to 120p. The game is worth the cost of an old console, hands-down. Iâ€™ve seen RDR at GameStop for $5, so it shouldnâ€™t be more than whatever the Irish equivalent of $100 is, total. (Donno if youâ€™re pounds or euros or if that split is still even a thing. I donâ€™t really pay attention... whoops.) Iâ€™m seeing used PS3s going for ~$80 on eBay right now, to give an idea of a price. Get the Game of the Year edition if you can find it, so you can play Undead Nightmare, too. Not pertinent to RDR2, but a great DLC worth the playthrough. Regardless what you end up doing, I hope youâ€™re able to enjoy the game as much as I have! nan

My experience with PSNow was actually really positive. No input lag, quick load times, no waiting. Still, I canceled after the 1-week trial because $20/mo. is outrageous to play old games worth $5 each. nan

once again i apologize for the poor sentence structure. when i'm typing i'm not paying attention to periods and paragraphs. so i agree i can make them run on... just bare (sp?) with me. the store in question is located in the pen centre in st. kitts. and i'm not going to mention the employee (aka - the store manager) by name since i think head office has already had a talk with them and now i may have an issue if it comes to having to go and pick up the codes. i find it quite funny that with more recent releases such as the call of duty WWII they can print DLC codes at the bottom of the receipt, yet they can't seem to do the same with steep or ghost recon. ghost recon especially since it's the newest of the two and it's still getting dlc and updates. yes, i know some dlc is only available at pre-order and day one release. BUT it can be done... and you would think if they can arrange it or dig up some codes that may still be valid why not just do that and have a satisfied customer rather than fan the flames of an irritated customer to the point they would never shop there again. heck, i could be that one customer that comes in a drops hundreds compared to the one that only buys a pair of cheap socks and a $1 cheap bin spinner. i get a chuckle out of these idiots that once promoted to store manager and given the key to the front and back door they think they actual hold some sort of power. lol, you're a game store salesperson.... who at any time could wind up unemployed if head office felt your location wasn't producing the sales they were expecting. if anyone wants to know what goes on at eb/gamestop i suggest you look up a youtube person by the name of "fantavision". he talks about working at gamestop and all sorts of stuff they would pull... including selling back free games they would get at conventions AND selling/claiming codes that were included in new games. one thing he does touch on is this. every new game eb/gamestop sells the developer gets a cut of, so they open the games and some they would claim as used so they would not have to give the developer their cut. it's hard for the developer to prove which is which since they claim they opened the game for "display purposes". gamestop then claims the game as open and used BUT to a customer such as myself, they claim it as new opened product to still get the full retail pricing. this was one reason why microsoft decided to include new releases in their version of PSnow... to cut out the middleman. and isn't it funny how of all the places like walmart, best buy, target, etc. that eb games/gamestop is the one complaining the loudest about potential loss of sales. at least walmart, target and best buy have other stuff in their stores to keep them afloat while eb/gamestop doesn't really. sure they have branched out to become hot topic lite, but places like hot topic have the better deals and clearance racks compared to the latter. so i'm thinking if sony follows suit to compete with microsoft that would leave eb/gamestop really struggling since they would depend on older games at that point... ones that aren't on the PSnow and xbox comparable. and even then, other game shops would sell the older games at a better price. my relative was actually able to get their steep dlc. they bought it through xbox live and actually got it included in another dlc free. so they are happy. and i get the free updates from ghost recon so i'm not upset. nan

Heard amazing things about New Vegas, and with PSNow having finally appeared in my country I started playing it. But Iâ€™m finding the game difficult to get used to. Maybe its because its a downgrade from 4, but Im having a hard time doing anything. Find it hard to aim and shoot, I run out of bullets so fast, and my health goes down really quickly. I set it on Very Easy just until I get the hang of it. I just got to Primm and I keep dying over and over again in that casino. My attacks do very little damage while the enemies, even weak ones, seem to do a lot to me. I know I will get better the more I play, but I just thought maybe you guys could offer me advice. I still play 4 and I am quite good at it, but 4 hours into New Vegas and I love it so far, I just cant seem to do anything right in it. Any tips for leveling up fast or getting better gun/ammo, so i can finish this Primm mission and move on? EDIT: Well I feel like an idiot. The game mode was aet on Very Hard, not Very Easy. Im using PSNow to play this, and my internet is good but occasionally PSNow lags slightly. It was lagging when I changed to Very Easy. With the lag, I think I accidentally went one too far all the way back around to Very Hard. All is good now though, flying through it and getting used to things :) Starting out New Vegas after Fallout 4 and finding it difficult. Would appreciate some advice.

Try to keep this short as I know this is a major known issue with FO3 running on Win 10. I have Steam GOTY Edition. It ran Vanilla with compatibility tweaks (ran compatible with XP SP3). Also, installed FOSE with compatibility, upped the .exe to 4 GB and set affinity for game at 2 cores. It ran even better seemed more stable. I also Installed Unofficial Patch. Okay now for MODS.; Fellout-Full, Enhanced Blood, Flora Overhaul, Colt M4 Carbines, GNR Enhanced, AKS74U, MMMFO, Sprint Mod, DC Interiors, Real World Drinks, Hi Res Weapons and the NMC Large Texture Pack. I had more loaded but it would crash shortly after execution (if it would even execute) so I scaled down my MOD selection. To my shock and surprise the game executed and loaded. 30 hours I had spent trying and troubleshooting. I was able to start a New Game. Played for several hours with only one crash. I got to Megaton (crashed again as I exited the vault but loaded save and worked swell thereafter for a while). I was so stoked, I had never seen FO3 like this I played it 10 years ago on console and never dreamed how good it could look now that I have a gaming CPU. Contents: You aren't streaming the game, you download them. It works like if you had bought the game digitally. (Not like Sony's PSNow). Think of it like Netflix but you download the movies/games first. nan

I recently signed up the Playstation Now seven day trial, which is absolutely free.After that point ,it's going to be 15 euro a month, which okay that's not too bad if the service is reliable - right? So, I see Fallout New Vegas - I'm extremely excited , I haven't played it in a long time, since I sold my PS3 a few years back to afford a PS4. So I click in to it, beautiful, it's actually working , the menu looks sharp and the intro rolls smoothly. Now I get in to gameplay, it looks worse than the PS3 version and the sound is compressed but not terrible. First thing I notice is the dreadful input lag, you know that sequence at the beginning when you shoot at bottles? I legitimately had trouble doing it, I missed a couple of times. The combat with the powder gangers was tough too because it was quite laggy, to be honest it just didn't feel right if that makes sense, everything was off in a small way. My speed varies from 10mbps to 50 mbps throughout the day, it never goes below 10 and the average low is honestly probably around 12-13. Got the go ahead, apparently the mininum you require to have a good experience is 5 mbps, gee I should be having a terrific experience if I have double that - wrong. In all honesty, I am willing to tolerate it as it's my favourite game whilst I have other games available , despite them having better graphics and zero input lag - because of nostalgia and because the writing is simply wonderful. Some of you should try it out, post your speeds and tell me your experiences. Thanks for reading! About Fallout New Vegas on PS4(ps now)
Post Title: About Fallout New Vegas on PS4(ps now)

Contents: Try to keep this short as I know this is a major known issue with FO3 running on Win 10. I have Steam GOTY Edition. It ran Vanilla with compatibility tweaks (ran compatible with XP SP3). Also, installed FOSE with compatibility, upped the .exe to 4 GB and set affinity for game at 2 cores. It ran even better seemed more stable. I also Installed Unofficial Patch. Okay now for MODS.; Fellout-Full, Enhanced Blood, Flora Overhaul, Colt M4 Carbines, GNR Enhanced, AKS74U, MMMFO, Sprint Mod, DC Interiors, Real World Drinks, Hi Res Weapons and the NMC Large Texture Pack. I had more loaded but it would crash shortly after execution (if it would even execute) so I scaled down my MOD selection. To my shock and surprise the game executed and loaded. 30 hours I had spent trying and troubleshooting. I was able to start a New Game. Played for several hours with only one crash. I got to Megaton (crashed again as I exited the vault but loaded save and worked swell thereafter for a while). I was so stoked, I had never seen FO3 like this I played it 10 years ago on console and never dreamed how good it could look now that I have a gaming CPU. I have an Alienware 15, getting a little long in the tooth in 2018 but it was smoking FO3. I did my thing at Megaton and played around with some console commands still chugging along. Then... Contents: Onlive tried it and failed. Gaikai tried it, was bought by Sony and merged into the lower stakes delivery of older games on a new platform through PSNow. Now, both Google and Microsoft have announced their intent to launch a streaming service. Both have extensive datacenters around the globe to minimize lag problems. Both have armies of engineers to optimize and solve problems. Microsoft already has a foot in the door with developers and publishers. Google already has its chromecast in many houses. https://www.theverge.com/2018/2/7/16986380/google-chromecast-game-streaming-android-mobile-tv-home-console https://www.slashgear.com/microsoft-cloud-gaming-division-sets-the-stage-for-post-xbox-streaming-15523346/ Now, lets be clear. You and me won't be their target demographic for years to come, but look where Steam was in 2003. In a decade and a half, Steam will need to be St(r)eam, or it's a relic. Pro's of streaming games as a consumer: - No upfront expensive hardware costs. - Games will run on a virtual machine in a datacenter, which are much easier to keep up and running as tech moves on. Want to play a 20 year old game in 2038, no problem. - Cheating will be impossible with all code run on the server. - Modding can still be made possible Cons as a consumer: - no gaming if your internet is down - Modding, even when possible, is likely not going to extend to radical stuff like an external scripting engine like SKSE/NVSE, or shaders. - Monthly subscription fees for yet another online service Pro's in general: - Hardware in datacenters can be utilized 24/7, no longer the massive waste of millions of dollars idling during the day in homes, and in offices at nights. Dramatically dropping costs of processing power for consumers and businesses alike Thoughts? Ideas? More pros or cons? You hate where it's going? For me, it feels like the 80's and the 90's were the era where we had to handcrank our cars to start them. The past two decades we had automatic starters but were still working on them every weekend to clean and fix them, and now we're heading into the era where it "just works". Streaming games - Phase 2
Post Title: Streaming games - Phase 2

Contents: Originally posted by Steve Mahanahan: Originally posted by MundM: So yeah, see you all in 10 years in Bloodborne on pc via emulator and a self hosted p2p server, lol. So, yeah. Cool, well all the emulator kiddies can feel free to get 10 summer jobs in a row and save enough for a PC good enough to emulate Bloodborn in any meaningful way. But, no there will never be a PC release of Des or Bloodborne. This is really simple and is parts exclusive rights. Same reason you will never see Super mario 64 with a native PC release. >BBuuububbuuut you can emulate that too. Ad hominem and straw man arguments, nices. Technology evolves. You can't stop that. A high end pc is middle class after the next gen hardware is released. My i5 cpu from 2012 is perfectly fine emulating ps2 games. A current gen 6 core i7 is already fine performing using the current ps3 emulator build, and that emu isn't even close to finished and optimized. In 5 years, Sony will have given up on most ps3 games, only some extreme high demanded games "might" get a remastered or remade version for PS5 or whatever it will be called then, and all other games will be forgotten if it wasn't for emulation and a very enthusiastic collectors community. Maybe psnow will be successful and all games will be streamable in console quality, that would be nice, because it sure is a more comfortable way to play these games, emulation was always something you have to get used to. Anyway, ps4 games might join psnow in the future, just as ps3 games are right now, and you can play these on pc, period. Nintendo games will join the pc in emulated form. I would like to point out the topic again: The game "never" being playable on pc. I said that's wrong and I statet why. We where not talking about "official" releases. Try to keep this short as I know this is a major known issue with FO3 running on Win 10. I have Steam GOTY Edition. It ran Vanilla with compatibility tweaks (ran compatible with XP SP3). Also, installed FOSE with compatibility, upped the .exe to 4 GB and set affinity for game at 2 cores. It ran even better seemed more stable. I also Installed Unofficial Patch. Okay now for MODS.; Fellout-Full, Enhanced Blood, Flora Overhaul, Colt M4 Carbines, GNR Enhanced, AKS74U, MMMFO, Sprint Mod, DC Interiors, Real World Drinks, Hi Res Weapons and the NMC Large Texture Pack. I had more loaded but it would crash shortly after execution (if it would even execute) so I scaled down my MOD selection. To my shock and surprise the game executed and loaded. 30 hours I had spent trying and troubleshooting. I was able to start a New Game. Played for several hours with only one crash. I got to Megaton (crashed again as I exited the vault but loaded save and worked swell thereafter for a while). I was so stoked, I had never seen FO3 like this I played it 10 years ago on console and never dreamed how good it could look now that I have a gaming CPU. I have an Alienware 15, getting a little long in the tooth in 2018 but it was smoking FO3. I did my thing at Megaton and played around with some console commands still chugging along. Then... I leave Megaton heading north and every time I get just beyond Sunnyvale, where you can see the large overpass it goes kaput. Only thing I can think is maybe Fellout or the NMC pack is adding in to much detail and I am running the game on ultra high settings. I played around with it a bit still no luck. I really don't want to lose Fellout mod it looks so amazing. IDK, if any of you friends read this and know something I haven't tried (and yes I have rifled through the forums and threads or as much as I could and still no dice) save me from having to play FO3 on ...gulp... PSNow . Oh the graphics are shhait and interface even worse. If you have read this far thanks much obliged. Sincerely, Hopeless Gamer in The OC (RehabJip) ====================::==================== I did make some progress by uninstalling NMCs Texture Pack. I don't know if ti was conflicting with Fellout or if I just had or have to many mods loaded. I got got out of Sunnyvale and game was playing great, no lag, AI was functioning and then just randomly crashed for no apparent reason. Any advice to make game more stable would be helpful. Primary issues are about a third of the time game will fail on launch or shortly after launch and will need to be relaunched. When game launches stable it crashes intermittently now (after removing NMC) with no real reason I can figure or any warning signs. Below are the details for my machine and software. Shes getting a bit antiquated (even back in 2015 when FO4 launched could not run on anything but low low settings on this thing) but should be more than enough for FO3. Alienware 15 R2 Laptop W/ Windows 10 Home (updated to current) Intel i5-6300HQ 2.3 GHz 8GB HDDR4 GeForce GTX 965M 1920X1080 Hard Drive HGST Travelstar 7K1000 1 Tb/ 400 Gb used Game Version: Fallout 3 GOTY Steam Edition (Fully Updated) extension- User/RehabJip/steamgames/steamapps/common/Fallout 3 goty I am using FOSE and 4gb Patch. I use NMM primaraly but also use FOMM when required. I have LOOT and FO3Edit. I am not hiding extensions. I'm tired and just wanna play? Anything I haven't tried? HELP! Fallout 3 Technical Support
Post Title: I'm tired and just wanna play? Anything I haven't tried? HELP! Fallout 3 Technical Support

Contents: >No switch version R ====================::==================== >>409868221 The original version of "Revenge of Shinobi" had Godzilla, Batman, and Spider-Man as bosses. None of these were licensed by their respective property owners to be used in the game, so Sega had to remove them in reprints of the Genesis carts or be sued. Marvel contacted Sega and let them freely use Spider-Man in his boss segment (it's an enemy disguised as Spider-Man), who then later morphs into Batman. They had to remove Batman and added in a Bat-like enemy instead. Godzilla got replaced with a generic T-Rex statue. When Marvel's licensing deal expired with Sega for the game, they had to omit "Revenge of Shinobi" from both the PS2 and PS3 Genesis collections. Someone at Sega figured out all they had to do was take Spider-Man and color him a solid pink. All legal issues were avoided and it got re-released on the Wii VC and PSNow. >No switch version R

Contents:
Microsoft has officially confirmed its plans for E3 2018. Rather than have its usual presence inside the Los Angeles Convention Center, where E3 takes place, Microsoft is moving the bulk of its efforts across the street to the nearby Microsoft Theater in LA Live. The company says this will make for the companyâ€™s â€œbiggest E3 showing ever.â€

First up at the Microsoft Theater will be Microsoftâ€™s E3 press conference, which is scheduled to take place on Sunday, June 10, at 1 PM PT. Following that, it will host Xbox FanFest events, hands-on demos for E3 attendees, and more. â€œNot only does the Microsoft Theater allow us to centralize our Xbox presence at E3, but its size enables us to include even more fans and partners in the Xbox E3 2018 Briefing than ever before,â€ said corporate VP Mike Nichols in an Xbox Wire post.

The announcement makes it clear that the move was made in collaboration with the ESA, no doubt to avoid spurring discussions about E3â€™s demise. Microsoft also points out that it wonâ€™t be absent entirely from the official E3 show floor, as it will have a booth for its streaming service, Mixer.

â€œThese changesâ€“expanding our presence, multiple venues, taking over the Microsoft Theaterâ€“give us the opportunity to bring together a variety of Xbox experiences into one primary location and, most importantly, let fans in on what weâ€™re up to in 2018 and beyond in a fresh new way,â€ Nichols said.

At this point, we have little idea of what to expect from Microsoftâ€™s E3 showing. Whereas last year we knew that Xbox One X (then Project Scorpio) would be a major highlight, this yearâ€™s show remains more of a mystery. Xbox boss Phil Spencer said in January that there would be some â€œpositive changesâ€ at E3 for Microsoft, which may have been a reference to the just-announced move. One possibility is the announcement of Halo 6, which has been discussed but not formally revealed. Microsoft is also said to be working on a PlayStation Now-like game-streaming service. Microsoft Reveals E3 Plans For Xbox's "Biggest Showing Ever"
Post Title: Microsoft Reveals E3 Plans For Xbox's "Biggest Showing Ever"

Contents: Playstation Now now available in Ireland* FTFY /s nan

Microsoft has set up a new cloud gaming division in the company to look forward to a future where its gaming strategy does not revolve around Xbox.

A window reflecting a nearby building at the Microsoft office in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US. Reuters.

If you are living under a rock or suddenly happen to read this article out of the blue then the Xbox is Microsoftâ€™s gaming console that is geared both towards gaming as well as living-room entertainment.

Currently, the innovation efforts from both the console makers or companies that focus on gaming PCs and the game developers are focused to make better-looking games, to make dedicated gaming devices (PCs and Consoles) more powerful while pushing for portability when it comes to hand-held devices (Nintendo Switch). Microsoft has been planning to move in a direction where the device does not matter and the gaming experience stays similar regardless of how powerful or portable the device is.

Nintendo Switch

According to a report by The Verge, as part of the planning, the company has been acquiring smaller companies that have been working on improving the gaming experience. Some of the acquisitions include Havok, Simplygon and more recently, PlayFab earlier this year. The report points out that these companies are essential to Microsoftâ€™s plans to launch its cloud gaming services.

The newly created cloud gaming division by Microsoft will be headed by 20-year Microsoft veteran Kareem Choudhry. Talking to The Verge, Kareem added, â€œPhil really wanted a dedicated team focused exclusively on the gaming cloud. Those were conversations that started happening last summer, and we really started creating the structure of the organization at the end of last year.â€ The company wants to push game developers to use the cloud as more and more games start providing an experience that spans multiple devices.

MicrosoftÂ is looking to create something that is like Netflix but for gaming where a subscription will give users access to whatever game they like, on whatever device they want to play the game on. However, Microsoft wonâ€™t be the only company with the ambition to offer a game streaming service. Sony tried its hand with PlayStation Now and Nvidia is also offering its gaming streaming service in the form of GeForce Now. This service is a difficult nut to crack while maintaining the quality and ease of use. However, Microsoft seems to be determined to offer this service in three years. Till then, it has a long way to go from getting the technology right to attracting gamers and game developers to the service.

Also See: Sonyâ€™s full-frame A7III mirrorless camera comes to India at a price of Rs 1,64,990

Microsoftâ€™s Teams is finally catching up with Slack thanks to deeper integration with Office: Report

Read more on Gaming by Firstpost. Microsoft creates a new gaming cloud division to look at a future beyond Xbox

I think remasters are partly just a function of publishers wanting to take on less risk. It's probably easier to develop and sell a remaster than a brand new IP. It can also be a good way to gauge interest in a dormant IP. For example, with the recent re-release of the Devil May Cry HD Collection on current-gen systems and PC there is a possibility Capcom could be testing the waters to see if there is interest in a another entry in the mainline series and not another spin-off/reboot like DmC. Microsoft is going to continue with their backwards compatibility strategy with titles from.multiple generations, and Sony would be stupid not to follow along as well. It will be possible because of the hardware they are using and it will give them a much larger game library at launch. Sony was likely betting on their PSNow service taking off as it would have cost them less money than attempting hardware native BC or software emulation. No one was expecting or predicting that MS would go the route they did with BC. Hell even MS wasnâ€™t planning on doing that until Mattrick was out and Spencer took over the Xbox division. nan

Contents: https://www.engadget.com/2018/03/15/...loud-division/ Quote: : With little fanfare, Microsoft has announced that it's launching a new gaming cloud division, a move that would set the company up to enter the world of game streaming. As The Verge reports, it's something Microsoft been building up for a while with the acquisition of small companies like PlayFab, which is focused on game development in the cloud. The company also has the basic structure of what a cloud streaming offering could look like with Xbox Game Pass, its subscription service that gives players access to large library of games for $10 a month. While early attempts at game streaming have crashed and burned, like OnLive, it's still an intriguing market. Sony's PlayStation Now service is still alive and kicking on the PS4 and PC, and NVIDIA is doubling down on game streaming with GeForce Now. The latter is still just a beta test though -- even the graphics card giant hasn't figured out how to charge for high-end game streaming. Microsoft isn't saying much about what the new gaming cloud division is working on yet, but its leader, Kareem Choudhry, hints that they're exploring ways to bring content to gamers on any device. Microsoft forms a new gaming cloud division

Contents: Whether or not that ends up being true or not, the takeaway is how much of a force Switch is having in the industry and the market. https://asia.nikkei.com/Markets/Tokyo-Market/Smash-hit-Switch-revives-Nintendo-and-supplier-stocks Itâ€™s currently the most heavily traded stock in the Tokyo market this last year Smash-hit Switch revives Nintendo and supplier stocks Game publishers seen as next in line to get boost from hybrid device YUKINORI HANADA, Nikkei staff writer TOKYO -- Nintendo ranks as the most heavily traded stock in the Tokyo market over the past year, as the company reclaimed its status as a top player in the video game industry with red-hot sales for the Switch console. The company was so unpopular back in 2015 that the president of an electronic parts company wanted to be dissociated from the Kyoto-based game maker. "Please don't call us a Nintendo-related stock anymore," the president said at a news conference for an earnings release. Inventories of Nintendo's disappointing Wii U device were building up at the time, leading to cuts in output plans that hurt electronic parts suppliers. But three years later, critics see Nintendo in a completely different light. The Switch, a hybrid game system that serves as both a home console or a handheld, has been flying off the shelves. Its U.S. sales have outpaced those of a popular predecessor, the Wii, encouraging Nintendo to upgrade the sales target twice for the year ending this month. Investors have shown their zeal for Nintendo, whose share price has more than doubled since the release of the Switch about a year ago. The stock's trading volume by value for the nearly concluded fiscal 2017 totaled roughly 25 trillion yen ($236 billion) as of Monday, more than twice the figure for second-place SoftBank Group. This revival compares with the murky outlook for suppliers of electronics company Apple. The U.S. company's top-tier iPhone X has driven consumers away with its lofty price tag. Apple now looks to curb prices by "putting cost-cutting pressure on parts suppliers," said Masamitsu Oki at Fivestar Asset Management. Nintendo buys fewer parts from outside suppliers than Apple, yet is influential enough to lift profits at some electronic parts developers. Shares have skyrocketed 62% for Minebea Mitsumi since the debut of the Switch, as the company is thought to build the device. Hosiden, which also assembles the Switch, and supplier MegaChips have surged more than 30% each. "The rally of parts suppliers will be followed by that of software publishers," predicts an official at Sumitomo Mitsui Asset Management. Nintendo has been creating game content mostly on its own, but third-party publishers are set to benefit from the Switch's booming sales. One of the most promising developers is Capcom, whose shares hit a 17-year high Monday on strong earnings and growing hopes tied to planned titles for the Switch. One big question involves whether the fervor for the Switch will be sustainable. Global sales will reach at least 200 million units, about twice as many as for the Wii, according to one estimate. Nintendo sees its operating profit more than quintupling to 160 billion yen this fiscal year. Nintendo seeks to sell consoles even at a loss, with the company more than erasing the red ink through high-margin software. This business model means that profits usually would begin three to four years after releasing a new gaming system. "It is highly possible that the company earns a record profit in fiscal 2019," predicts Hideki Yasuda at Ace Research Institute. Video game sales generally are shielded from the economic cycle. As data at home and abroad hints at an economic slowdown, investors are shying away from blue chips such as banks and electrical machinery manufacturers -- making it even more likely that Nintendo and its suppliers will remain a driving force of the Tokyo market in the near term ====================::==================== SaltSlasher said: â†‘ If we're talking 200 million, Switch is gonna have to average 50 million among NA, EU, JP and WW, EACH, and the only machines to get a 50 in 1 of the 4 categories was PS2 in NA and EU, and DS in NA and EU, and they were both in the market for over 10 years each. Yet, JP's max has been 33, and WW is 25. So even if we took the best of each 4 regions from any machines, NA 57 + EU 55 + JP 33 + WW 26 that is roughly 170 million. Predicting Switch sells 200 million is insanely high, and yeah I know an iPhone can sell a couple hundred million in a year, but damn, Switch just ain't gonna put 1 in each hand at $300. Click to expand... I agree. I am sure however there will be drastic price drops in the future, time will tell, but for sure in 2019. It could be that Nintendo releases a new SKU this year, which I didnt think of till the update came. Even then though, without a price drop for Christmas, it will be 25 million this fiscal year even with smash and pokemon. But forget phone comparisons, it is an apples to oranges comparison, one is almost a necessity and the other is a toy. I personally always felt Switch would easily break 20 million in Japan, and maybe could be best selling device in JP history, selling like 40 million. And I wouldn't be shocked if they sold 40 million in NA, plenty of machines have done that, but I just don't see EU and WW numbers getting that high, and NA and JP would have to compensate, and even if EU and WW do break records, NA and JP would still have to compensate on top to get to 200. Nintendo easily has 70 million fans willing to buy product, biggest thing they can do is get 1 person to buy a 2nd one with a refresh but I just don't see the same collectors edition thing happening on Switch like with 3DS where people own like 5 of them to have different styles, not when Joy Cons are for that, I see 200 million Joy Cons being sold. But I just don't see the whole 1 switch per kid/person unless they do a major refresh and kid brother gets the old Switch, not that buying 1 for each kid at Christmas. 1 time in my childhood anything remotely happen, when I got a GBC and my sister got a Tiger Game.com...and even her household has like 4-5 3DS's, they never went out and bought 2 at a time. Click to expand... I dont see how you cant see households with multiple Switches with different styles, it is already here. Some people already have a grey and another colored joycon Switch to differentiate them. I think I'd predict +100 million, IF: Click to expand... -No one else releases a handheld. Nvidia Shield Tablet 2 would be really interesting. Xbox's cloud and service gaming is interesting. And PlayStation's Now service can get interesting, as would a new handheld. Click to expand... The only competition I could see to Nintendo's handheld space is Apple entering the ring with a more focused all in one handheld phone gaming system. -Started selling just the Switch with no dock for $200 and packed in Splatoon 2/Odyssey/or other newer games. Click to expand... I can see that sooner than you think. -They can keep up with demand all the time, not the constant inventory issues Click to expand... Nintendo has new partners for hardware manufacturing instead of only having just one now. They wont have issues in the future unless they start selling over 30 million a year. I forsee comparison videos about the different Switch models with different parts. -Switch has a full mid-gen upgrade refresh Click to expand... It seems that is coming this year or the next. -Switch is in market for more than 6 years, I want to say 8-10 Click to expand... Highly likely. If the 3DS is anything to go by, Nintendo will support it for a few more years after they come up with a new system. -The market for Steam indies in handheld is a bigger market than I've always thought and people buy Switch just for indies Click to expand... There are people who are already doing this, but at best they will make up like 5% of the switch population, ie buy switch mainly for indies. -Nindies starts publishing games for indie devs lto get more exclusivity with Steam with no PS4/Xbox Click to expand... Eh? Why would they need to do that? The switch is already a preferred system for indies over the PS4 and Xbox. -Nintendo goes crazy developing a crap ton of games for every gamer, like no stone unturned, hype every year for 6+ years. Click to expand... Define crap ton? I see Nintendo more than doubling their output since they seem to be almost doubling it now with all the outsourcing they are doing now. With little fanfare, Microsoft has announced that itâ€™s launching a new gaming cloud division, a move that would set the company up to enter the world of game streaming. As The Verge reports, itâ€™s something Microsoft been building up for a while with the acquisition of small companies like PlayFab, which is focused on game development in the cloud. The company also has the basic structure of what a cloud streaming offering could look like with Xbox Game Pass, its subscription service that gives players access to large library of games for $10 a month.

While early attempts at game streaming have crashed and burned, like OnLive, itâ€™s still an intriguing market. Sonyâ€™s PlayStation Now service is still alive and kicking on the PS4 and PC, and NVIDIA is doubling down on game streaming with GeForce Now. The latter is still just a beta test though â€“ even the graphics card giant hasnâ€™t figured out how to charge for high-end game streaming. Microsoft isnâ€™t saying much about what the new gaming cloud division is working on yet, but its leader, Kareem Choudhry, hints that theyâ€™re exploring ways to bring content to gamers on any device.
The Verge
 * This article originally appeared on Engadget. Microsoft forms a new gaming cloud division
Post Title: Microsoft forms a new gaming cloud division

Contents: With the recent surge of popularity, do you think there is a chance for a PS3 Collection on the 4? We know its possible but do you think Sega would do it? I doubt we'll see remakes and remasters of Y4 and Y5. They're both massive games and they are already available on PSNow via the PS4. Y5 could probably get a more native PS4 release simply by upscaling the resolution and scrapping the interlacing it seems to use. But, I wouldn't rule out a Y3 remaster though. The game looks incredibly dated, even by PS3 standards, and its western release was heavily censored and cut back vs the Japanese release. They've successfully built a lot of momentum in the west with the releases of Zero and Kiwami, and the relatively quick follow up of Y6, and the recent announcement of localization of K2. Moving forward with a Kiwami remake for Y3 would keep that momentum moving and it'd be a smaller undertaking them trying to remake the much larger Y4 and Y5 games. nan

New Post has been published on http://loopnews.info/microsoft-creates-a-new-gaming-cloud-division-to-look-at-a-future-beyond-xbox-technology-news-firstpost/

Microsoft creates a new gaming cloud division to look at a future beyond Xbox- Technology News, Firstpost





Microsoft has set up a new cloud gaming division in the company to look forward to a future where its gaming strategy does not revolve around Xbox.

A window reflecting a nearby building at the Microsoft office in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US. Reuters.

If you are living under a rock or suddenly happen to read this article out of the blue then the Xbox is Microsoftâ€™s gaming console that is geared both towards gaming as well as living-room entertainment.

Currently, the innovation efforts from both the console makers or companies that focus on gaming PCs and the game developers are focused to make better-looking games, to make dedicated gaming devices (PCs and Consoles) more powerful while pushing for portability when it comes to hand-held devices (Nintendo Switch). Microsoft has been planning to move in a direction where the device does not matter and the gaming experience stays similar regardless of how powerful or portable the device is.

Nintendo Switch

According to a report by The Verge, as part of the planning, the company has been acquiring smaller companies that have been working on improving the gaming experience. Some of the acquisitions include Havok, Simplygon and more recently, PlayFab earlier this year. The report points out that these companies are essential to Microsoftâ€™s plans to launch its cloud gaming services.

The newly created cloud gaming division by Microsoft will be headed by 20-year Microsoft veteran Kareem Choudhry. Talking to The Verge, Kareem added, â€œPhil really wanted a dedicated team focused exclusively on the gaming cloud. Those were conversations that started happening last summer, and we really started creating the structure of the organization at the end of last year.â€ The company wants to push game developers to use the cloud as more and more games start providing an experience that spans multiple devices.

MicrosoftÂ is looking to create something that is like Netflix but for gaming where a subscription will give users access to whatever game they like, on whatever device they want to play the game on. However, Microsoft wonâ€™t be the only company with the ambition to offer a game streaming service. Sony tried its hand with PlayStation Now and Nvidia is also offering its gaming streaming service in the form of GeForce Now. This service is a difficult nut to crack while maintaining the quality and ease of use. However, Microsoft seems to be determined to offer this service in three years. Till then, it has a long way to go from getting the technology right to attracting gamers and game developers to the service.

Source link nan

Whether or not that ends up being true or not, the takeaway is how much of a force Switch is having in the industry and the market. https://asia.nikkei.com/Markets/Tokyo-Market/Smash-hit-Switch-revives-Nintendo-and-supplier-stocks Itâ€™s currently the most heavily traded stock in the Tokyo market this last year Smash-hit Switch revives Nintendo and supplier stocks Game publishers seen as next in line to get boost from hybrid device YUKINORI HANADA, Nikkei staff writer TOKYO -- Nintendo ranks as the most heavily traded stock in the Tokyo market over the past year, as the company reclaimed its status as a top player in the video game industry with red-hot sales for the Switch console. The company was so unpopular back in 2015 that the president of an electronic parts company wanted to be dissociated from the Kyoto-based game maker. "Please don't call us a Nintendo-related stock anymore," the president said at a news conference for an earnings release. Inventories of Nintendo's disappointing Wii U device were building up at the time, leading to cuts in output plans that hurt electronic parts suppliers. But three years later, critics see Nintendo in a completely different light. The Switch, a hybrid game system that serves as both a home console or a handheld, has been flying off the shelves. Its U.S. sales have outpaced those of a popular predecessor, the Wii, encouraging Nintendo to upgrade the sales target twice for the year ending this month. Investors have shown their zeal for Nintendo, whose share price has more than doubled since the release of the Switch about a year ago. The stock's trading volume by value for the nearly concluded fiscal 2017 totaled roughly 25 trillion yen ($236 billion) as of Monday, more than twice the figure for second-place SoftBank Group. This revival compares with the murky outlook for suppliers of electronics company Apple. The U.S. company's top-tier iPhone X has driven consumers away with its lofty price tag. Apple now looks to curb prices by "putting cost-cutting pressure on parts suppliers," said Masamitsu Oki at Fivestar Asset Management. Nintendo buys fewer parts from outside suppliers than Apple, yet is influential enough to lift profits at some electronic parts developers. Shares have skyrocketed 62% for Minebea Mitsumi since the debut of the Switch, as the company is thought to build the device. Hosiden, which also assembles the Switch, and supplier MegaChips have surged more than 30% each. "The rally of parts suppliers will be followed by that of software publishers," predicts an official at Sumitomo Mitsui Asset Management. Nintendo has been creating game content mostly on its own, but third-party publishers are set to benefit from the Switch's booming sales. One of the most promising developers is Capcom, whose shares hit a 17-year high Monday on strong earnings and growing hopes tied to planned titles for the Switch. One big question involves whether the fervor for the Switch will be sustainable. Global sales will reach at least 200 million units, about twice as many as for the Wii, according to one estimate. Nintendo sees its operating profit more than quintupling to 160 billion yen this fiscal year. Nintendo seeks to sell consoles even at a loss, with the company more than erasing the red ink through high-margin software. This business model means that profits usually would begin three to four years after releasing a new gaming system. "It is highly possible that the company earns a record profit in fiscal 2019," predicts Hideki Yasuda at Ace Research Institute. Video game sales generally are shielded from the economic cycle. As data at home and abroad hints at an economic slowdown, investors are shying away from blue chips such as banks and electrical machinery manufacturers -- making it even more likely that Nintendo and its suppliers will remain a driving force of the Tokyo market in the near term ====================::==================== SaltSlasher said: â†‘ If we're talking 200 million, Switch is gonna have to average 50 million among NA, EU, JP and WW, EACH, and the only machines to get a 50 in 1 of the 4 categories was PS2 in NA and EU, and DS in NA and EU, and they were both in the market for over 10 years each.
